The descriptor of the bias.
The activation function that the layer applies to the output.
The width increment of the input image.
The height increment of the input image.
The width increment between elements in the input image during convolution.
The height increment between elements in the input image during convolution.
The width padding, which is the number of virtual zeros added to the top and bottom of each channel.
The height padding, which is the number of virtual zeros added to the top and bottom of each channel.
The number of convolution groups.
Padding which is asymmetric and ignored if the width or height padding values are greater than zero.
If
is greater than 1, the layer uses input, output, weights, and bias for a set of convolutions, and you must meet the following:
Input and output channels must be divisible by groups.
The layout of the weights descriptor must be
The size of the second dimension of the weights must equal the number of input channels.
The size of the third dimension of the weights must equal the number of output channels.
When calling apply forward and backward functions,
, and gradient strides should be the strides for the entire convolution group.
This functionality isn’t supported in transposed convolution.
Convolution layers only support arrays with a data type of
, or

abstract.text: Make large-scale mathematical computations and image calculations, optimized for high performance and low energy consumption.
A set of parameters that describe common activation functions.
A constant that represents a 4D array of rotated convolution weights.
A constant that represents a 4D array of convolution weights.
A constant that represents a 4D array of packed convolution weights with 32-output channel packing and 128-byte array address alignment.
A constant that represents a 4D array of rotated convolution weights.
A constant that represents a 3D image stack.
A structure that contains the parameters of a convolution layer.
Returns a new convolution layer parameters structure.
Returns a new convolution layer parameters structure from the specified parameters.
A structure that describes the shape, stride, data type, and, optionally, the memory location of an n-dimensional array.
